questions.text: In paracetamol poisoning, N-acetylcysteine is administered as an antidote. How does it act to prevent toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Management of Paracetamol poisoning

Management Aspect

Details

Initial Treatment
  • Gastric Lavage
  • Administer activated charcoal or cholestyramine (effective within 30 minutes of ingestion)

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) Therapy
  • Initiate within 8 hours of ingestion; may be partially effective up to 24–36 hours post-overdose.
  • Administration:
  • IV: 140 mg/kg loading dose over 1 hour, followed by 70 mg/kg every 4 hours for 15–20 doses.

Mechanism of Action
  • NAC acts as a sulfhydryl donor, replenishing glutathione.
  • Neutralizes toxic metabolites and prevents binding to cell proteins, reducing the severity of hepatic necrosis.

Liver Transplantation
  • Considered in cases of hepatic failure (jaundice, coagulopathy, confusion).
  • King's College Criteria is used to predict the need for a liver transplant in patients with paracetamol-induced acute liver failure :
  • Arterial blood pH < 7.30

Or all of the following:

  • Prothrombin time (PT) > 100 seconds (INR > 6.5)
  • Serum creatinine > 300 μmol/L
  • Grade III or IV hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: What is the treatment of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Omeprazole

E

questions.text: Proton pump inhibitor suppresses gastric acid secretion by acting on?
questions.explanation:
Proton pump inhibitor

MOA

It inhibits the H+/K+ ATPase pump located in the parietal cells of the stomach, thus reducing acid secretion in the stomach.

Potency of PPI
  • Rabeprazole > Lansoprazole > Rabeprazole > Omeprazole > Pantoprazole
  • All PPIs have equal efficacy.

Properties

  • Acid production reduction persists for 2 to 4 days even after stopping the drug and resumes later.
  • Duration of action is typically 2 to 4 days.
    • Omeprazole is the fastest acting PPI.
    • PPIs are acid labile; Enteric coating can protect from acid degradation.
    • They should be taken on an empty stomach when only ~I0% of proton pumps are active, followed 1 hour later by a meal to activate the H+/K+/ATPase at a time when plasma concentration of the PPI is maximal.

Side effects

  • Chronic use of PPIs can lead to hypergastrinemia, which can further result in:
    • ECL hyperplasia
    • Fundic gland polyposis
    • Atrophic gastritis
  • Gastrointestinal upset (nausea, constipation, diarrhoea)
  • Increased microbial growth leads to a higher risk of bacterial infection
  • Increased risk of bone fractures due to hypocalcemia (reduced absorption of calcium)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Diphenylmethane

Prokinetic

Prokinetic agents are medications that enhance gastrointestinal motility and promote the movement of food through the gastrointestinal tract.

Drugs

5-HT4 agonist - stimulates 5-HT4 in the GIT, which causes increased release of Acetylcholine and enhances GIT motility

  • Naronapride
  • Cisapride
  • Prucalopride

Dopamine antagonist - blocks dopamine receptors in the GIT, which reduces the inhibitory effects of dopamine on the GIT motility.

  • Metocloprimde
  • Domperidone

Motilin agonist - Mimics the action of motilin, which promotes GIT motility

  • Erythromycin (Off-label)
  • Camicinal

Miscellaneous

  • Sincalide - C-terminal octapeptide of CCK
  • Relamorelin - Ghrelin agonist

Uses
  • Gastrointestinal reflux disease
  • Gastroparesis
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Postoperative ileus

Adverse effects

  • Gastrointestinal disturbance (Diarrhoea, Vomiting, abdominal cramps)
  • Headache
  • Dizziness
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms with Dopamine antagonist

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of profuse, watery stools and an elevated WBC count of 16000 cells/mm3. He has been on treatment with amoxicillin for the past 1 week. What is the treatment of choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Drugs which increase the risk of Pseudomembranous colitis

Drugs useful in Pseudomembranous colitis
  • Clindamycin
  • Cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone)
  • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin)
  • Penicillins (e.g., ampicillin, amoxicillin)
  • Metronidazole
  • Vancomycin
  • Fidaxomicin
  • Rifaximin

questions.text: A patient was started on antitubercular therapy. After 10 days, investigations were done. AST and ALT levels were within normal limits but serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL and serum uric acid was 10 mg/dL. The patient also complains of diffuse joint pains. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop pyrazinamide and continue isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol.

options.label: B
options.text: Add allopurinol and stop isoniazid, continuing other ATT drugs with monitoring.

options.label: C
options.text: Continue all ATT drugs and start high-dose corticosteroids for joint pains.

options.label: D
options.text: Stop ethambutol and continue other ATT drugs with uric acid monitoring.

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop pyrazinamide and continue isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice (DOC) for treating morning sickness in pregnant women?
Which of the following drugs is used in GERD?
A patient underwent gastrointestinal surgery and had her jejunum resected. Which of the following drugs should be added to her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Teduglutide

Type

Peptide hormone (GLP-2 analogue )

Mechanism of Action

Teduglutide ⟶ Binds to GLP-2 Receptors on Intestinal epithelial cells ⟶ Activation of Guanylate Cyclase ⟶ Increased production of cGMP ⟶ Activation of Protein Kinase G⟶ Regulation of Tight Junctions and Epithelial transporters ⟶ Enhanced intestinal absorption of fluid and nutrients ⟶ Improved glycemic control.

Uses

Treatment of short bowel syndrome (SBS) in adult patients who are dependent on parenteral support.

Benefits
  • Reduces dependence on parenteral nutrition
  • Improves intestinal absorption and transit time
  • Increases nutrient absorption and fluid balance

Side Effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Headache
  • Upper respiratory tract infection

Contraindications
  • Gastrointestinal obstruction or perforation
  • Gastrointestinal cancer

Special Points
  • Requires subcutaneous injection
  • Dosing and adjustment should be based on individual patient responses.
  • Regular monitoring of nutritional status and fluid balance is essential.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a patient presenting with diarrhea and a flask-shaped ulcer on a colonoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Tissue Amebicidal Drugs

 

Metronidazole

 
  1. DOC for all forms of amebiasis
  2. Treats amebic colitis and liver abscess
  3. Penetrates well into body tissues and fluids, including vaginal secretions, seminal fluid, saliva, breast milk, and cerebrospinal fluid.
  1. Effective against Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites but less effective against cysts.
  2. Inhibits protein synthesis in Entamoeba
  3. Treats giardiasis, trichomoniasis, and anaerobic infections
  4. Used in combination therapy for H. pylori infection

Tinidazole

 

Amebic colitis and liver abscess

Also used to treat Trichomoniasis.

Ornidazole

Acute amoebic dysentery

 

Secnidazole

Emetine

Acute amoebic dysentery or amoebic liver abscess in patients not tolerating metronidazole
  • Directly acting amoebicide that kills trophozoites but has no effect on cysts.
  • Side effects include vomiting and cardiotoxicity.

Chloroquine

Amoebic liver abscess

Kills the liver stage of Entamoeba histolytica

Luminal Amebicidal Drugs

Drug

Uses

Additional points & S/E

Paromomycin

(DOC)

An Aminoglycoside

Luminal agent for amebiasis.

An alternative drug for Giardiasis, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy where metronidazole is C/I.

Diloxanide furoate

Mild intestinal amebiasis

Furoate is the active moiety that kills Entamoeba

Quiniodochlor

 

Rarely used due to dangerous side effects such as SMON (Subacute myelo-optico-neuropathy)

Iodoquinol

Contains iodine and can cause thyroid abnormalities and allergy

Luminal Amebicidal Drugs

Tissue Amebicidal Drugs
  • Paromomycin
  • Diloxanide furoate
  • Quiniodochlor
  • Iodoquinol
  • Metronidazole or its congeners (Tinidazole, Ornidazole)
  • Emetine
  • Chloroquine

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 6 hours after ingesting a large quantity of paracetamol tablets. What is the most likely progression of paracetamol poisoning in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in liver enzymes within 24 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Paracetamol achieves peak concentration within 4 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in liver enzymes within 24 hours
questions.explanation:
Metabolism of Acetaminophen
  • Acetaminophen is mainly metabolized via phase II reactions into harmless sulfate and glucuronide metabolites.
  • A small portion undergoes phase I metabolism by CYP2E1, forming the hepatotoxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI).

Detoxification of NAPQI

  • NAPQI is neutralized by binding to glutathione, forming water-soluble mercapturic acid, which is excreted via the kidneys.

Glutathione Depletion

  • When excessive NAPQI is produced, or glutathione is depleted, NAPQI binds to hepatocyte macromolecules, forming acetaminophen-protein adducts, causing hepatocyte necrosis.

Risk Factors
  • Chronic alcohol use (induces CYP2E1, depletes glutathione).
  • Starvation.
  • Prior use of mixed-function oxidase-inducing drugs (e.g., phenobarbital, INH).
  • Hepatitis C infection increases the risk of liver injury in overdose.

Clinical features

Early Symptoms (4-12 hrs):

  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, shock.

Delayed Symptoms (24-48 hrs):

  • Hepatic injury becomes apparent.
  • Coagulopathy and encephalopathy.
  • Maximal damage seen 3–5 days post-ingestion with aminotransferase levels >10,000 IU/L.
  • Renal failure and myocardial injury may occur.

Stages of acute acetaminophen poisoning

Stage

Time Post-Ingestion

Description

I

0–24 hours

Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.

II

24–72 hours

Right upper quadrant abdominal pain; elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), and sometimes increased bilirubin and INR if poisoning is severe.

III

72–96 hours

Vomiting, signs of liver failure; peak levels of AST, ALT, bilirubin, and INR. Possible renal failure and pancreatitis.

IV

> 5 days

Recovery of liver function or progression to multiple organ failure.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Peptic ulcer

Drug Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs)

Omeprazole, Esomeprazole, Lansoprazole

Inhibit the proton pump (H+/K+ ATPase) in gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

Histamine H2 Receptor Antagonists

Ranitidine, Famotidine, Cimetidine

Block the histamine H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

Antacids

Aluminum hydroxide, Magnesium hydroxide

Neutralize gastric acid, providing temporary relief from symptoms and promoting ulcer healing.

Mucosal Protective Agents

Sucralfate, Misoprostol

Enhance mucosal defense mechanisms, promote mucosal healing, and reduce acid secretion.

Antibiotics

Amoxicillin, Clarithromycin, Metronidazole

Used in combination therapy to eradicate Helicobacter pylori infection, which is associated with peptic ulcers.

M1 Blockers

Pirenzepine, Telenzepine

Selectively block muscarinic M1 receptors in the gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion and promoting ulcer healing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female comes to the OPD for well-care visits. The patient is completely well and eats a balanced diet . She never smokes or drinks alcohol and has no significant past medical history . On examination, her vitals are normal. The patient tells the physician that next week she will go on a trip to an island and is worried about motion sickness . Which of the following drugs may be considered first-line therapy for this patient's prophylaxis of motion sickness?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Prometh

Anti-Emetic

Conditions

Promethazine

Motion sickness, postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), vertigo

Ondansetron

Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), radiation-induced nausea and vomiting, gastroenteritis

Metoclopramide

Gastroparesis, chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

Domperidone

Gastroparesis, postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), GERD

Prochlorperazine

Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), vertigo, migraine-associated nausea and vomiting

Dimenhydrinate

Motion sickness, vertigo, vestibular disorders

Scopolamine

Motion sickness, postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)

Aprepitant

Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)

Dexamethasone

Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), acute severe nausea and vomiting
